title: Window Light Portraits
description: The most beautiful, most accessible portrait lighting requires only a window.

hook.text: Vermeer painted portraits by window light 400 years ago. Today, the most flattering portrait lighting still comes from a large window with indirect light. No flash, no studio, no expensive gear â€” just a window.

buildup.text: Setup: subject faces the window at 45 degrees. The window is a large, soft light source that wraps around the face with beautiful shadow transition. Avoid direct sunlight through the window â€” sheer curtains diffuse it perfectly.

discovery.text: The closer the subject to the window, the softer and more dramatic the light (brighter face, darker shadow side). Move them farther away for more even, less dramatic lighting. Distance from window controls contrast.

twist.text: Add a white surface (foam board, white wall, even a white t-shirt) on the shadow side to bounce light back and fill the dark side. This $0 reflector does the same job as expensive fill lights in professional studios.

climax.text: Position someone near a north-facing window (no direct sun). Place them at 45Â° to the window, add a white reflector on the shadow side. Take the photo. You'll get studio-quality portrait lighting from everyday materials.

punchline.text: The best portrait lighting is free. Find a window and you've found a studio.

quiz.question: How do you control contrast in window light portraiture?
options: Adjust the subject's distance from the window â€” closer means more dramatic contrast
